awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Unsteady Ground Effect: How Solid Boundaries Affect Bio-Inspired Propulsion
awd_abstract_narration:
Many animals fly or swim near the surface of water or the ocean floor.  These boundaries create unsteady, three-dimensional, and asymmetrical flows that can increase the animal's flying/swimming speed and efficiency. Despite the wide implications of these benefits, there are no reliable models for near-boundary bio-locomotion. Accurate models could reshape the way biologists think about the flight strategies of birds migrating over open water or the evolutionary pressures on the shapes of bottom-dwelling fish. A better understanding of near-boundary lifestyles could help ecologists better predict the fragility of near-ground ecosystems to over-fishing, loss of habitat, or changing climate. Better models would also reshape the way engineers design bio-inspired vehicles that operate near boundaries. The key to improving these models is a better understanding of the complex flows governing near-boundary swimming and flying. The proposed work aims to shed light on these complex flows and bring them into public view using multimedia and an outreach program for middle school girls. 
 
The goal of this project is to understand the unsteady flow mechanisms governing near-boundary swimming. The project will support the first systematic study of unsteady ground effect through a combination of water channel experiments and inviscid flow simulations. As a result, classic steady ground effect theory will be generalized to the modern interdisciplinary flow phenomena present in swimming and flying animals. These flow phenomena will be explored by testing the effects of Strouhal number, reduced frequency, aspect ratio, undulation, and asymmetric kinematics on near-ground swimming. The research will focus on four specific aims: (i) developing scaling laws for the forces and energetics of near-ground swimming, (ii) mapping near-ground three-dimensional flow interactions, (iii) determining the role of undulatory kinematics in near-ground swimming, and (iv) understanding how asymmetrical kinematics alter near-ground flows. By including both experiments and inviscid simulations, the research will identify which effects are Reynolds-number dependent and which are driven purely by inviscid vortex dynamics.  This research will provide key insights into the near-ground lifestyles of fish and will aid in the design of novel bio-inspired underwater vehicles.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
In this research project we have examined and detailed the hydrodynamic mechanisms and performance benefits of fish that swim near the ground (benthic fish). Many benthic flatfish are an important food source such as flounder, plaice, turbot, and halibut. Understanding the hydrodynamics of near ground swimming allows scientists to better understand the swimming capabilities and energy use of flatfish, which can lead to better estimates of the fragility of fish populations and could alter fishing quotas to better protect our ecosystems. This is especially important as climate change makes fish populations more likely to experience scarcity in their food sources.  Understanding unsteady ground effect also helps engineers who are designing and building the next generation of underwater robots that swim like fish and can take advantage of swimming near the ocean floor. Our research goals were: (1) Determining how thrust and efficiency scale with Strouhal number, reduced frequency, and altitude-to-chord ratio. (2) Determining how tip vortices affect the flow around near-ground finite-span fins, and how these three-dimensional wakes affect the scalings. (3) Determining how undulation-driven near-ground wakes (wavelength-to-chord < 1) compare to oscillation-driven near-ground wakes (wavelength-to-chord > 1). (4) Determining what wake asymmetries are introduced by asymmetrically-actuated near-ground fins.

Through our research we discovered and probed the existence flow-mediated equilibrium states between a swimmer and the ground where a swimmer is stable at an altitude from the ground to perturbations due to the forces that arise from the fluid flow.  A major conclusion that we have found is that indeed these equilibria exist in constrained two- and three-dimensional swimmers as long as the aspect ratio is greater than 1.  The equilibrium altitude depends upon the aspect ratio and the kinematics of the swimmers.  We have further determined that performance benefits occur at these equilibria, however, they may not be the peak performance locations.  We have also determined that the equilibria arise from a competition of wake-induced and quasi-steady forces.  Lastly, we have found scaling laws for the thrust, efficiency, and equilibrium altitudes of two-dimensional ground effect swimmers.  All these results will have a large impact on providing estimates of the energetic benefit of swimming near the ground, an understanding of the role of fluid forces in the equilibrium altitudes, and an understanding of the flow mechanisms behind these features. By understanding the flow mechanisms that alter the performance of swimmers near the ground we are learning more about three-dimensional vortex-body interactions thereby impacting our understanding of schooling interactions and interactions in oscillating hydrofoil energy extraction devices.

On the educational side we have also brought this research to the classroom to discuss results that we have found on unsteady ground effect as an example of modern research in fluid mechanics. We have completed the development of an educational module for Lehigh University's Charting Horizons and Opportunities in Careers in Engineering and Science (CHOICES) program that engages middle school girls in engineering modules.  The ground effect module has students designing the shape, flexibility, and ground distance of a twiddle fish for a competition to find the fastest swimmer.  This basic design competition exposes students to the performance effects of fish swimming near the ground, which are important for their survival. We further discuss some of the basic findings of our NSF research.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/29/2023
Modified by: Keith W Moored
